data.title: Is St Barts too French?

data.text:
I agree with Cassidain, when he says, "What bothers me is having to insist to service personnel that we converse en français rather than en anglais." This is my main irritant about St. Barth. Store and restaurant personnel have a very annoying desire to immediately turn the conversation to English (even though I'm not exactly a slouch in French). I NEVER have this problem in l'Hexagone (mainland France). I prefer to find people on St. Barth who speak only French, and spend time with them.

MikeR stated, "how about more french language and less american language and less tolerance by the locals for those dumbass tourists who couldn't be bothered to learn enough French to even be able to order a freakin baguette in the bakery without having to resort to grunting and pointing like some kind of primate." Well, unfortunately, there seems to be little appreciation, among those in the tourist trade on St. Barth, for Americans who do put in the effort to learn the language. These Americans are greeted by tourist trade workers who assume that they speak better English than the "language-impaired American" speaks French. I have never found anyone selling baguettes on St. Barth who wasn't fluent in English, and very anxious to use it, with Americans.

these are all good points....quite a few years ago my wife became very friendly with the woman who managed the Petit Colombe in Colombier....and they would sit and have coffee and speak in French to each other, and the woman was very disturbed as to how the island was "adjusting" to the American invasion and how service people, specifically the people at Petit Colombe, were being told to learn English and speak English and how upsetting this was to her...and my wife of course would tell her how wrong that was....this woman sadly got cancer and returned to France and we never heard from her again....Jim, my wife is a very very laid back Vermont country girl.....very little gets her rattled....but she can't even go into Petit Colombe anymore because she gets so pissed off at the sell out..in her mind if you can't tell them in their language what you want.....than starve!!!!

and don't even get her started on all the English in the menus there...as she says...how many American restaurants in resorts have you been in which have another language sub titled in the menu????.....in this country if you can't read the menu in our language, than that's your problem....and in her view, it should be the same way in a country which claims to be French.....and on and on...

you and her and cassidain would certainly get along on this topic
